title: Luke Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who mingled the blood of the Galilaeans with their sacrifices according to Luke 13?
options: Pilate
Herod
Jesus
The Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Pilate
questions.explanation: Luke 13:1 states that Pilate mingled the blood of the Galilaeans with their sacrifices.

questions.question: What did Jesus say would happen to all unless they repent?
options: They shall likewise perish
They shall be forgiven
They shall be blessed
They shall be healed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall likewise perish
questions.explanation: In Luke 13:3, Jesus says, 'except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish.'

questions.question: How many years had the man been seeking fruit on the fig tree in the parable?
options: Three years
One year
Five years
Seven years
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: Luke 13:7 mentions that the man had come seeking fruit on the fig tree for three years without finding any.

questions.question: What did the dresser of the vineyard ask to do with the fig tree?
options: Let it alone this year and dung it
Cut it down immediately
Water it daily
Move it to another vineyard
questions.correctAnswer: Let it alone this year and dung it
questions.explanation: In Luke 13:8, the dresser asks to let the fig tree alone for one more year and dig about it and dung it.

questions.question: On what day was Jesus teaching in a synagogue when he healed a woman?
options: Sabbath
Monday
Friday
Sunday
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbath
questions.explanation: Luke 13:10 states that Jesus was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.

questions.question: How long had the woman with a spirit of infirmity been bowed together?
options: Eighteen years
Ten years
Five years
Twenty years
questions.correctAnswer: Eighteen years
questions.explanation: Luke 13:11 describes the woman as having a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years.

questions.question: What was the ruler of the synagogue's reaction to Jesus healing on the Sabbath?
options: He was indignant
He praised Jesus
He was silent
He asked for a miracle
questions.correctAnswer: He was indignant
questions.explanation: Luke 13:14 says the ruler of the synagogue answered with indignation because Jesus healed on the Sabbath.

questions.question: According to Jesus, what is the kingdom of God like in the first parable he told in this chapter?
options: A grain of mustard seed
A pearl of great price
A lost sheep
A great flood
questions.correctAnswer: A grain of mustard seed
questions.explanation: Luke 13:19 describes the kingdom of God as like a grain of mustard seed that grows into a great tree.

questions.question: In the second parable about the kingdom of God, what is it likened to?
options: Leaven hidden in three measures of meal
A treasure hidden in a field
A good Samaritan
A wise builder
questions.correctAnswer: Leaven hidden in three measures of meal
questions.explanation: Luke 13:21 compares the kingdom of God to leaven which a woman hid in three measures of meal until it was all leavened.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the gate that one must strive to enter?
options: It is strait
It is wide
It is open to all
It is hidden
questions.correctAnswer: It is strait
questions.explanation: Luke 13:24 instructs to strive to enter in at the strait gate because many will seek to enter and not be able.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said that many will enter the kingdom of God easily.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 13:24 states that many will seek to enter the kingdom of God but shall not be able, implying it is not easy.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus referred to Herod as a fox in this chapter.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Luke 13:32, Jesus refers to Herod as 'that fox.'

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said a prophet cannot perish outside Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 13:33 states that a prophet cannot perish outside Jerusalem.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Luke 13:34: 'O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, which killest the prophets, and stonest them that are sent unto thee; how often would I have gathered thy children together, as a hen doth gather her ______ under her wings, and ye would not!'
options: brood
chickens
doves
sparrows
questions.correctAnswer: brood
questions.explanation: Luke 13:34 uses the metaphor of a hen gathering her brood under her wings to describe Jesus' desire to protect Jerusalem's children.

questions.question: According to Luke 13, who will be first and last in the kingdom of God?
options: Last shall be first, and first shall be last
First shall be first, and last shall be last
All will be equal
Only the greatest shall enter
questions.correctAnswer: Last shall be first, and first shall be last
questions.explanation: Luke 13:30 states that there are last which shall be first, and first which shall be last.

medium.title: Luke Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of guilt over past sins. Based on Luke 13:1-5, what biblical truth would you share about repentance and judgment?
options: Repentance is necessary to avoid perishing, regardless of others' sins.
Only those who commit great sins need to repent.
Judgment only falls on those who suffer publicly.
Suffering is proof of being a greater sinner.
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance is necessary to avoid perishing, regardless of others' sins.
questions.explanation: Luke 13:1-5 teaches that those who suffered (Galilaeans and those under the tower of Siloam) were not worse sinners, but all must repent or perish. This shows repentance is universally required.

questions.question: How does the parable of the fig tree in Luke 13:6-9 teach us about God's patience and personal spiritual growth?
options: God gives time and care to help us bear fruit before judgment.
God immediately punishes those who do not produce fruit.
Fruitfulness is not important in a believer’s life.
The fig tree represents people who will never change.
questions.correctAnswer: God gives time and care to help us bear fruit before judgment.
questions.explanation: In Luke 13:6-9, the owner wants to cut down the fig tree for no fruit, but the gardener pleads for more time to nourish it, illustrating God's patience and desire for our spiritual growth.

questions.question: A believer is hesitant to serve in the church because of physical limitations. What does Luke 13:10-17 teach about God's grace and inclusion in ministry?
options: God values and heals those burdened, enabling them to serve.
Only the physically strong should serve in ministry.
Healing is only for those who deserve it.
Sabbath rules prohibit helping the disabled.
questions.correctAnswer: God values and heals those burdened, enabling them to serve.
questions.explanation: Luke 13:10-17 shows Jesus healing a woman crippled for 18 years on the Sabbath, emphasizing God's compassion and the importance of enabling all to participate in ministry.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ response to the synagogue ruler in Luke 13:14-16 teach humility and compassion in church leadership?
options: Leaders should act with mercy, not hypocritical judgment.
Leaders must strictly enforce rules without exception.
Only certain people deserve healing and help.
Sabbath rules are more important than compassion.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should act with mercy, not hypocritical judgment.
questions.explanation: Jesus calls the ruler a hypocrite (Luke 13:14-16) for criticizing healing on the Sabbath, teaching leaders to prioritize compassion over rigid legalism.

questions.question: Based on Luke 13:18-21, what practical lesson on faith and influence can be drawn from the kingdom of God being compared to a mustard seed and leaven?
options: Small acts of faith can grow to impact many.
Only large, visible works matter in God's kingdom.
The kingdom of God grows quickly without effort.
Faith is only for personal benefit, not for others.
questions.correctAnswer: Small acts of faith can grow to impact many.
questions.explanation: The mustard seed and leaven parables (Luke 13:18-21) illustrate how small beginnings in faith can expand and influence many lives, encouraging perseverance and witness.

questions.question: A believer wonders if many will be saved. What does Luke 13:22-30 teach about the nature of salvation and the effort required?
options: Salvation requires striving to enter through the narrow gate.
Most people will easily enter the kingdom without effort.
Salvation is guaranteed for all who claim to know Jesus.
Only a few are saved, and nothing can change that.
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation requires striving to enter through the narrow gate.
questions.explanation: Luke 13:24 emphasizes the need to 'strive to enter in at the strait gate' as many will try but not succeed, highlighting the seriousness and effort needed for salvation.

questions.question: How does Luke 13:25-27 warn believers about superficial faith and the importance of genuine relationship with God?
options: Knowing Jesus’ teachings is not enough without true obedience.
Simply attending church guarantees entry to heaven.
Calling Jesus 'Lord' guarantees salvation without works.
Faith is only about feelings, not actions.
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing Jesus’ teachings is not enough without true obedience.
questions.explanation: Verses 25-27 describe people being denied entry despite familiarity with Jesus because He 'knows them not,' stressing that genuine faith requires obedience and relationship.

questions.question: According to Luke 13:28-29, what does the passage teach about God’s kingdom and inclusivity in the eternal fellowship?
options: People from all over will be included in God's kingdom.
Only a specific ethnic group will enter the kingdom.
The kingdom is exclusive to those born in Jerusalem.
Salvation is limited to prophets and patriarchs.
questions.correctAnswer: People from all over will be included in God's kingdom.
questions.explanation: Luke 13:28-29 shows people coming from east, west, north, and south to sit in the kingdom, indicating God’s inclusive plan for salvation beyond ethnicity.

questions.question: What does Luke 13:30 teach about humility and the reversal of worldly status in God's kingdom?
options: Those who are last now may be first in God's kingdom.
Worldly status guarantees priority in heaven.
God's kingdom rewards the proud and powerful first.
Social position has no bearing on eternal outcomes.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who are last now may be first in God's kingdom.
questions.explanation: Verse 30 teaches the principle that earthly rankings are reversed in God's kingdom, encouraging humility and contentment.

questions.question: A believer fears opposition for following Christ. Based on Luke 13:31-33, what encouragement does Jesus give about perseverance in ministry?
options: Jesus will continue His work despite threats until His mission is fulfilled.
Ministry can be abandoned if danger arises.
Prophets are safe from harm in their work.
Avoid conflict by stopping ministry when opposed.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus will continue His work despite threats until His mission is fulfilled.
questions.explanation: In verses 31-33, Jesus acknowledges threats but commits to continuing His mission, encouraging perseverance despite opposition.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ lament over Jerusalem in Luke 13:34-35 demonstrate His heart for evangelism and compassion for those who reject the Gospel?
options: Jesus deeply desires to save people even when they reject Him.
Jesus quickly gives up on those who do not believe.
Evangelism is optional and not urgent.
Rejecting the Gospel has no consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus deeply desires to save people even when they reject Him.
questions.explanation: Luke 13:34-35 shows Jesus sorrowfully lamenting Jerusalem’s rejection, illustrating His longing to gather and save people despite their refusal.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 13:3 and 13:5, repentance is optional for believers to avoid destruction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Both verses (Luke 13:3 and 13:5) clearly state that unless you repent, you will likewise perish, showing repentance is essential.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus healed the woman with the spirit of infirmity on the Sabbath to show that mercy transcends legalistic rules (Luke 13:10-17).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus heals the woman on the Sabbath and rebukes the ruler for hypocrisy, teaching mercy over legalism (Luke 13:12-17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Luke 13:7, the man said to the vineyard dresser, 'Behold, these three years I come seeking fruit on this fig tree, and find ____.'
options: none
some
much
a little
questions.correctAnswer: none
questions.explanation: The man expresses frustration that after three years, the fig tree bore 'none' fruit, highlighting the expectation of spiritual fruitfulness (Luke 13:7).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the difficulty of entering God’s kingdom. According to Luke 13:24, what attitude should they adopt?
options: Strive diligently to enter through the narrow gate.
Give up because entry is impossible.
Depend on others to enter for you.
Ignore the kingdom because it is too hard.
questions.correctAnswer: Strive diligently to enter through the narrow gate.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 urges believers to strive to enter the strait gate, emphasizing active effort and perseverance in faith.

hard.title: Luke Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 13.

questions.question: In Luke 13:6-9, the parable of the fig tree illustrates what theological concept related to God's patience and judgment?
options: God's patience with sinners before final judgment
The sudden destruction of the wicked
The eternal punishment of the unrepentant
The importance of vineyard farming in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God's patience with sinners before final judgment
questions.explanation: Luke 13:6-9 presents the fig tree that is given extra care to produce fruit, symbolizing God's patience and the opportunity for repentance before judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus healing the woman on the Sabbath in Luke 13:10-17, especially in relation to Jewish law and Pharisaic interpretation?
options: It challenges legalistic interpretations by emphasizing mercy over ritual
It shows Jesus disregarding the Sabbath commandments
It promotes working on the Sabbath as lawful
It emphasizes the necessity of rest over healing
questions.correctAnswer: It challenges legalistic interpretations by emphasizing mercy over ritual
questions.explanation: Jesus heals a woman bound by infirmity on the Sabbath and rebukes the ruler for hypocrisy, highlighting mercy's priority over strict Sabbath rules (Luke 13:14-16).

questions.question: In Luke 13:18-21, Jesus uses the mustard seed and leaven as metaphors for the Kingdom of God. What Old Testament imagery or concepts do these parables recall?
options: The growth of God's kingdom from small beginnings to widespread influence
The judgment of Israel by foreign nations
The exile and return of the Jewish people
The temple sacrifices and cleansing rituals
questions.correctAnswer: The growth of God's kingdom from small beginnings to widespread influence
questions.explanation: The mustard seed and leaven parables symbolize the Kingdom's humble start and transformative growth, reflecting Old Testament themes of God's expanding reign (Luke 13:19,21).

questions.question: According to Luke 13:3 and 13:5, what is the universal condition necessary to avoid perishing, as taught by Jesus?
options: Repentance
Faith alone
Ritual sacrifice
Observance of the Law
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance
questions.explanation: Jesus emphasizes that except one repents, all will likewise perish, making repentance essential for salvation (Luke 13:3,5).

questions.question: The phrase 'there are last which shall be first, and there are first which shall be last' in Luke 13:30 is an example of what literary device?
options: Paradox
Simile
Hyperbole
Metonymy
questions.correctAnswer: Paradox
questions.explanation: Luke 13:30 uses paradox to challenge conventional social rankings, emphasizing reversal in God's kingdom.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ response to the Pharisees in Luke 13:31-33 reflect His awareness of His mission and its timing?
options: He acknowledges His destined path to Jerusalem despite threats
He agrees to flee to avoid danger
He calls for immediate rebellion against Herod
He plans to stop performing miracles
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges His destined path to Jerusalem despite threats
questions.explanation: Jesus states He must continue His journey to Jerusalem because a prophet cannot perish outside it, showing His commitment despite danger (Luke 13:33).

questions.question: In Luke 13:34-35, Jesus laments over Jerusalem. What Old Testament theme is He echoing with His comparison to a hen gathering her brood?
options: God’s protective love contrasted with Israel’s rejection
The promise of an everlasting kingdom
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The call to build the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protective love contrasted with Israel’s rejection
questions.explanation: Jesus’ metaphor of a hen gathering her chicks recalls God’s tender care for Israel contrasted with their rejection and violence toward prophets, reflecting themes from Hosea and other prophets (Luke 13:34).

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 13:24, Jesus teaches that entering the kingdom of God is effortless and guaranteed for all who seek it.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Luke 13:24 that one must 'strive to enter in at the strait gate' because many will seek but not be able to enter, indicating effort is required.

questions.question: Which historical figure is mentioned in Luke 13:1 as having mingled the blood of Galileans with their sacrifices?
options: Pilate
Herod
Caesar Augustus
Caiaphas
questions.correctAnswer: Pilate
questions.explanation: Luke 13:1 refers to Pontius Pilate mingling Galileans' blood with their sacrifices, indicating his role in violent suppression.

questions.question: What is the significance of the number eighteen in the context of Luke 13:4 and 13:11?
options: It marks prolonged suffering and judgment
It is a symbolic number of perfection
It represents the age of majority
It indicates the number of disciples
questions.correctAnswer: It marks prolonged suffering and judgment
questions.explanation: Eighteen years is the duration of the woman's infirmity (Luke 13:11) and the number of people killed by the falling tower (Luke 13:4), symbolizing human suffering and the need for repentance.

questions.question: In Luke 13:26-27, what reason does Jesus give for rejecting those who claim to know Him but are called 'workers of iniquity'?
options: He does not know them because they lack true obedience
They have not attended synagogue regularly
They have performed miracles in His name
They have given offerings to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He does not know them because they lack true obedience
questions.explanation: Jesus denies knowing those who call Him Lord yet practice iniquity, emphasizing obedience over mere familiarity (Luke 13:27).

questions.question: The mustard seed parable in Luke 13:19 is a typological foreshadowing of which broader New Testament theme?
options: The expansion of the Church from small beginnings
The judgment of the nations
The fall of Jerusalem
The destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The expansion of the Church from small beginnings
questions.explanation: The mustard seed growing into a large tree prefigures the Church’s growth and inclusion of Gentiles, a theme developed in Acts and Paul’s epistles (Luke 13:19).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Luke 13:15, Jesus calls the synagogue ruler a '_____,' criticizing his hypocrisy regarding Sabbath observance.
options: hypocrite
servant
teacher
blasphemer
questions.correctAnswer: hypocrite
questions.explanation: Jesus calls the ruler a 'hypocrite' in Luke 13:15 because he allows animals to be freed on the Sabbath but condemns healing a woman, exposing inconsistent application of the law.

questions.question: How does Luke 13:29 emphasize the inclusiveness of the Kingdom of God, and what Old Testament prophecy does this echo?
options: People from all directions will join the kingdom, echoing Isaiah's vision of the Gentiles coming to Zion
Only Israelites from Jerusalem will enter the kingdom, echoing Deuteronomy's covenant exclusivity
The kingdom is limited to the twelve tribes, reflecting Jacob's blessings
The kingdom is restricted to priests, reflecting Levitical law
questions.correctAnswer: People from all directions will join the kingdom, echoing Isaiah's vision of the Gentiles coming to Zion
questions.explanation: Luke 13:29 shows people coming from east, west, north, and south, reflecting Isaiah 43:5-6's prophecy about Gentiles joining God's people.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 13:22-24 suggests that salvation is guaranteed for those who merely acknowledge Jesus publicly.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus emphasizes in Luke 13:24 that many will seek to enter but not be able to, indicating that mere acknowledgment is insufficient for salvation.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Luke 13, how does Jesus respond to the notion that the Galileans punished by Pilate were greater sinners than others?
options: He denies that they were sinners above others and calls for repentance
He confirms they were the greatest sinners
He ignores the question
He says their punishment was unrelated to sin
questions.correctAnswer: He denies that they were sinners above others and calls for repentance
questions.explanation: Jesus explicitly rejects the idea that the Galileans were greater sinners and instead emphasizes the necessity of repentance to avoid perishing (Luke 13:2-3). This aligns with passages such as John 3:16-18 emphasizing repentance, Romans 3:23 on universal sinfulness, Ezekiel 18:23 on God's desire for repentance, and Acts 17:30 which calls all to repent.

questions.question: What is the significance of the fig tree parable in Luke 13, and what does the owner decide to do after three years of no fruit?
options: The tree is given one more year for cultivation before being cut down
The tree is immediately cut down
The tree is ignored and left to grow wild
The tree is transplanted to another vineyard
questions.correctAnswer: The tree is given one more year for cultivation before being cut down
questions.explanation: In the parable, the owner seeks fruit for three years and finds none, then commands the tree to be cut down, but the gardener pleads for one more year to cultivate it (Luke 13:6-9). This illustrates God's patience and opportunity for repentance, consistent with 2 Peter 3:9, Romans 2:4, and Isaiah 55:6-7, emphasizing God's longsuffering towards sinners.

questions.question: What was the condition of the woman Jesus healed in the synagogue on the Sabbath, and how long had she suffered?
options: She was bowed down by a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years
She had leprosy for seven years
She was blind from birth
She was mute for ten years
questions.correctAnswer: She was bowed down by a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years
questions.explanation: Luke 13:11-12 describes a woman who had been bent over for eighteen years due to a spirit of infirmity. Jesus heals her on the Sabbath, demonstrating His authority and compassion, which aligns with Isaiah 61:1-3 on healing and liberation, Mark 2:27 on Sabbath purpose, and Matthew 12:12 on doing good on the Sabbath.

questions.question: What argument does Jesus use to defend healing on the Sabbath when challenged by the synagogue ruler?
options: That people routinely care for their animals on the Sabbath, so healing a person is lawful
That the Sabbath law does not apply to healings
That the ruler misunderstood the law
That healing is more important than the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: That people routinely care for their animals on the Sabbath, so healing a person is lawful
questions.explanation: Jesus calls the ruler a hypocrite for allowing animals to be freed on the Sabbath but objecting to healing a daughter of Abraham (Luke 13:14-16). This reflects God's design for Sabbath mercy and restoration, consistent with Hosea 6:6, Matthew 12:7, and the principle of mercy over sacrifice in Scripture.

questions.question: How does Jesus describe the kingdom of God using the mustard seed in Luke 13?
options: As something that starts small but grows into a large tree where birds can nest
As a large tree from the very beginning
As a tiny seed that never grows
As a seed that produces no fruit
questions.correctAnswer: As something that starts small but grows into a large tree where birds can nest
questions.explanation: Jesus likens the kingdom of God to a mustard seed that begins small but grows into a large tree providing shelter (Luke 13:18-19). This symbolizes the humble beginnings and expansive growth of God's reign, consistent with Matthew 17:20, Daniel 4:12, and Psalm 1:3 illustrating growth and blessing.

questions.question: In Luke 13, what does the kingdom of God resemble when compared to leaven?
options: It is like leaven hidden in three measures of meal that leavens the whole
It is like leaven that remains separate from the meal
It is like leaven that spoils the meal
It is like leaven that is discarded
questions.correctAnswer: It is like leaven hidden in three measures of meal that leavens the whole
questions.explanation: Jesus compares the kingdom of God to leaven a woman hid in three measures of meal until all was leavened (Luke 13:20-21). This metaphor depicts the pervasive and transformative power of God's kingdom, aligning with Old Testament symbolism of leaven (Exodus 12:15), and New Testament teaching on growth and influence (1 Corinthians 5:6-8, Matthew 13:33).

questions.question: What instruction does Jesus give regarding entering through the 'strait gate'?
options: Strive to enter, because many will try and fail
Enter casually, for the gate is wide open
Avoid the gate, because it leads to destruction
Wait for an invitation to enter
questions.correctAnswer: Strive to enter, because many will try and fail
questions.explanation: Jesus warns to 'strive to enter in at the strait gate' as many will seek to enter but not be able (Luke 13:24). This calls for diligent pursuit of salvation, consistent with Matthew 7:13-14 on narrow gate, Hebrews 12:1-2 on perseverance, Philippians 3:14 on pressing toward the goal, and Revelation 3:5 on overcoming.

questions.question: What response does Jesus say the master of the house will give to those knocking after the door is shut?
options: He will say, 'I know you not whence ye are; depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity'
He will open the door immediately
He will welcome them without question
He will send them to another house
questions.correctAnswer: He will say, 'I know you not whence ye are; depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity'
questions.explanation: Jesus describes a time when the master shuts the door and denies knowing those outside who claim familiarity, calling them workers of iniquity (Luke 13:25-27). This reflects the necessity of true faith and obedience, in line with Matthew 7:21-23, 2 Timothy 2:19, and John 10:27-28 on genuine belonging to Christ.

questions.question: What is described as happening in the kingdom of God in Luke 13:28-29?
options: There will be weeping outside as many see the patriarchs sitting in the kingdom
Only Jews will enter the kingdom
The kingdom will be small and exclusive
No one from the north or south will be included
questions.correctAnswer: There will be weeping outside as many see the patriarchs sitting in the kingdom
questions.explanation: Luke 13:28-29 describes those excluded from the kingdom weeping and gnashing teeth as they see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and prophets inside, and people coming from all directions to sit down in God's kingdom. This emphasizes inclusion by faith and the consequences of rejection, consistent with Romans 11:17-25, Galatians 3:28-29, and Isaiah 56:6-8.

questions.question: What paradox does Jesus reveal about the status of the first and the last in the kingdom of God?
options: The last shall be first, and the first shall be last
The first shall always remain first
The last shall be last forever
There is no change in status
questions.correctAnswer: The last shall be first, and the first shall be last
questions.explanation: Luke 13:30 states a reversal of worldly expectations in God's kingdom, where social or temporal status is reordered. This paradox is echoed in Matthew 19:30, Mark 10:31, and James 2:5, illustrating God's sovereignty and grace in salvation.

questions.question: How does Jesus respond to the Pharisees' warning about Herod's intent to kill Him?
options: He calls Herod 'that fox' and declares He will be perfected after three days
He agrees to flee immediately
He plans to confront Herod
He ignores their warning
questions.correctAnswer: He calls Herod 'that fox' and declares He will be perfected after three days
questions.explanation: Jesus refers to Herod as 'that fox' and states He will continue His work of casting out devils and healing until the third day when He will be perfected (Luke 13:31-32). This alludes to His death and resurrection, fulfilling prophecy (Psalm 22, Isaiah 53), and the divine mission (John 10:18, Acts 2:23).

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the necessity of His journey to Jerusalem despite the threats against Him?
options: A prophet cannot perish outside Jerusalem, so He must go
He will avoid Jerusalem to save His life
He will only go if protected
His mission is complete elsewhere
questions.correctAnswer: A prophet cannot perish outside Jerusalem, so He must go
questions.explanation: Jesus declares that it is necessary to walk to Jerusalem because a prophet must perish there, fulfilling the destiny of messengers rejected by the city (Luke 13:33). This connects to prophetic fulfillment (Jeremiah 26:18), the rejection of Jesus (Matthew 23:37), and God's redemptive plan (Luke 9:51).

questions.question: How does Jesus express His sorrow over Jerusalem in Luke 13:34?
options: He laments that Jerusalem kills prophets and refuses His gathering
He celebrates Jerusalem's faithfulness
He ignores Jerusalem's sins
He curses the city
questions.correctAnswer: He laments that Jerusalem kills prophets and refuses His gathering
questions.explanation: Jesus mourns over Jerusalem for killing prophets and rejecting His protective invitation, likening His desire to a hen gathering chicks under her wings (Luke 13:34). This reflects God's enduring love despite human rejection, consistent with Hosea 11:1, Matthew 23:37, and Romans 5:8 on divine compassion.

questions.question: What prophecy does Jesus make about Jerusalem in Luke 13:35 regarding His future visibility to them?
options: They will not see Him until they say, 'Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord'
They will see Him immediately after His departure
They will never see Him again
They will see Him only in secret
questions.correctAnswer: They will not see Him until they say, 'Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord'
questions.explanation: Jesus prophesies that Jerusalem's house will be left desolate and they will not see Him until a future time when they recognize Him as the Messiah (Luke 13:35). This points to eschatological fulfillment and recognition of Christ, aligning with Psalm 118:26, Zechariah 12:10, and John 1:11-12.

questions.question: What is the theological implication of Jesus calling the woman healed on the Sabbath a 'daughter of Abraham'?
options: It affirms her covenant identity and right to liberation
It implies she was physically Abraham's daughter
It means she was an Israelite priestess
It suggests she was excluded from God's promises
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms her covenant identity and right to liberation
questions.explanation: By calling her a 'daughter of Abraham' (Luke 13:16), Jesus affirms her inclusion in the covenant people and the legitimacy of her healing, reflecting God's intent to bless descendants of Abraham (Genesis 12:3, Galatians 3:7, Romans 4:16), and emphasizing the dignity and worth of all covenant members.
